Dialogs.Name: Introduction
Dialogs.Content: The interlocking spirals found in the <color=maroon>seeds</color>, <color=red>petals</color> and even <color=maroon>branches</color> of many <color=green>plants</color> occur naturally through the growth of the flower. This model attempts to demonstrate the growth of these naturally occurring spirals.
Dialogs.Title: Welcome to the Sunflower Model! 

Buttons.Text: Want to know more? Click here for higher level reading!

Dialogs.Name: WhatIsIt
Dialogs.Title: Welcome to the Sunflower Model! 
Dialogs.Content: When a new <color=maroon>seeds</color> emerges, the older ones grow slightly and move further from the center--the source--and the youngest <color=maroon>seeds</color> finds the largest gap between existing <color=maroon>seeds</color>, in which it can grow. This gap can be found by turning <trigger=counterclockwise>counterclockwise</trigger>.

The angle made by this turn is a multiple of the <trigger=golden-ratio,olive>golden ratio</trigger> (1.618). The <color=olive>golden ratio</color>, based on the <trigger=fibonacci>Fibonacci series</trigger> (1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13...), equals the <trigger=limit>limit</trigger> of F(n)/F(n-1). Thus, these spirals can be mathematically generated, using the <color=olive>golden ratio</color>.
Dialogs.Name: Fibonacci-Angle
Dialogs.Title: The Golden Ratio 

Buttons.Text: Why do the <color=green>turtles</color> form a circle?

Dialogs.Name: HowItWorks
Dialogs.Title: How It Works
Dialogs.Content: For each <trigger=clock-tick>clock-tick</trigger> , a new <color=green>turtle</color> (which can be seen as a <color=maroon>seed</color> or a <color=red>petal</color>) is created. As in nature, the <color=green>turtle</color> finds the <trigger=appropriate-position>appropriate position</trigger> and begins growing. All of the other existing <color=green>turtle</color> move forward and grow slightly, with each clock-tick.

Dialogs.Name: Circle
Dialogs.Content: If a <color=green>turtle</color> gets too close to the edge of the world and too far from the center of the world, it dies. That is the reason they form a circular pattern .
Dialogs.Title: Death Beyond the Edge 

Dialogs.Name: ShowWidget
Dialogs.Content: Onwards! Let's continue exploring this model. Click on the highlighted button to open the widgets panel.
Dialogs.Title: Widgets Panel 

Dialogs.Name: WidgetTest
Dialogs.Title: num-colors 
Dialogs.Content: The NUM-COLORS slider controls how many colors the turtles can be. (Using this will make some of the spirals stand out more, other stand out less.) Try changing the value of num-colors.

Dialogs.Name: WidgetTest2
Dialogs.Title: step-size 
Dialogs.Content: The STEP-SIZE slider controls how far away the turtle moves from the center, for each clock-tick. Try changing the value of step-size.

Dialogs.Name: WidgetTest3
Dialogs.Title: turn-increment 
Dialogs.Content: The TURN-INCREMENT slider dictates the degree that each new turtle will turn to set its position in the spiral. Try changing the value of turn-increment.

Dialogs.Name: WidgetTest4
Dialogs.Title: set turn-increment 
Dialogs.Content: The SET TURN-INCREMENT buttons help to set the TURN-INCREMENT slider to specific values at and around the <color=olive>golden ratio</color>. They are simply there to help achieve precision  that can be difficult with the slider. Try clicking on one of the buttons.

Dialogs.Title: Things to Try
Dialogs.Content: Try making the model draw your favorite flower's <color=red>petal</color> or <color=maroon>seed</color> pattern . For example, a buttercup or columbine could be made by creating 5 large petals of the appropriate <color=red>c</color><color=orange>o</color><color=navy>l</color><color=magenta>o</color><color=teal>r</color><color=cyan>s</color>.

Dialogs.Name: ThingsToTry5
Dialogs.Title: Things to Try
Dialogs.Content: Here's a challenge! In nature, real plantsdon't have the <trigger=golden-ratio,olive>golden ratio</trigger> "programmed" into them. Rather, the spirals form as the result of an <trigger=emergent-process>emergent process</trigger>, described in Conway and Guy's book and other sources. Can you extend this model to capture this emergent process?
The number of clock-ticks times the turn 'increment'
